## The machine learning victories at the 2024 Nobel Prize Awards and how to explain them 
Machine learning using apparently different architectures bagged the 2024 Nobel Prizes for Physics and Chemistry. Anna Demming reports on what the prizes were awarded for and how finding connections between the two approaches to machine learning may help towards explaining how "black box" algorithms reach their conclusions.   
:::
::: {.g-col-12 .g-col-lg-8 .top-story-img}
![](ideas/posts/2024/10/31/images/Nobelpic-shutterstock-991.png)
:::

Welcome to **Real World Data Science**, a new project from the [Royal Statistical Society](https://rss.org.uk/), in partnership with the [American Statistical Association](https://www.amstat.org/). We bring together data science students, practitioners, leaders, and educators to share knowledge, learn from, and be inspired by real-world applications of data science.
:::

## Is data science a new and exciting set of skills, necessary for analyzing 21st century data? Or is it (as some have claimed) a rebranding of statistics, which has carefully developed time-honored methods for data analysis over the past century? In this article, we use two popular data science algorithms to examine the difference between data science, statistics, and other occupations. 
Jonathan Auerbach, David Kepplinger, and Nicholas Rios ask, 'What is data science?'

::: {.button}
[Read their analysis](ideas/posts/2024/02/19/what-is-data-science.qmd)

## Generative AI is based on neural networks, which are so-called ‘black boxes’. This makes it difficult or impossible to explain the inner workings of the model which has potential implications if in the future you are challenged to justify decisioning or guidance based on the model.
